timeline.message: Pass VoiceCommands to operation instead of RPC
Update pending tasks when callback returns new list
Refactor and cancel tasks before clearing queue

timeline.bodyText: The manager always logs that error message even if there are no errors
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: Updated to only print when errorObject is not empty
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: it doesn't seem that there is currently a way for the developer to delete existing voice commands. Developers may expect the existing items to be deleted when an empty list is passed but currently, the method just returns in that case. Does iOS have the same behavior?
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: Updated to allow for an emptylist to be set, added unit test for the updateOperation
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: This class shouldn't be public
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: I suggest wrapping this in a null checking condition
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: Do we still need this boolean after using queues? I believe the main reason for using queues is not to use such conditions
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: In this method (line 141), we are still manually checking HMI and return if it is NONE. That should be handled by pausing and resuming the queues instead.
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -125,9 +148,9 @@ public void setVoiceCommands(List<VoiceCommand> voiceCommands) {
         waitingOnHMIUpdate = false;

timeline.message: Fix review feedback allow empty list to be set
Remove old HMIStatus logic and allign with iOS

timeline.bodyText: We shouldn't update voice commands in the case where the devs set the same voice commands as existing ones (iOS implementation has that)
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: We don't need to setlastVoiceCommandId again
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: currentVoiceCommands shouldn't be updated until we make sure the voiceCommands are successfully sent to the head unit otherwise currentVoiceCommands could have wrong values (if sending the RPC fails for example). Please check how is that implemented in iOS to align with that.
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: removed this to align with iOS code
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: I suggest removing the update() method and host its logic directly in setVoiceCommands() because the update() is only called one time and to align more with iOS
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: removed update method and added to set voice commands
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: We are setting updateOperation to null twice in this method
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: removed assignment in the transactionQueue check
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: I am a little confused about we do we need two variables (this.oldVoiceCommands, this.currentVoiceCommands) if they both point to the same object
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: If I understand it correctly, we need to keep an updated copy of the current voice commands so we add and remove from currentVoiceCommands based on RPC responses. But since currentVoiceCommands  & oldVoiceCommands  both point to the same object, modifying the first will change the second as well. which makes oldVoiceCommands value incorrect. In that case currentVoiceCommands should be a deep copy of oldVoiceCommands. Because we dont want to alter oldVoiceCommands when we make changes to the items in currentVoiceCommands
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: changed to copy oldVoiceCommands into currentVoiceCommands
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure what onError() does exactly in Taskmaster, does the queue continue executing other operations? we need to confirm that. Or we can call onFnished() regardless of the RPC response result to let the queue continue
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: Changed to onFinished() as this is how it was implemented for other tasks such as SoftButtonReplaceOperation and TextAndGraphicUpdateOperation
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: I suggest doing a null check before updateVoiceCommands just to be extra sure that the object is not null
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi
bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: We can exit out of the loop when we find the item that we are searching for
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: change no longer needed due to change in the onResponse methods
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: We can exit out of the outer loop when we find the item
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText:
in the if (!success) part, we find the request for the corresponding correclationId. Can we just pass that the command id for the request that we found to removeCurrentVoiceCommandWithCorrelationId() instead of passing the correclationId?. that way, we don't have to look for the request again in removeCurrentVoiceCommandWithCorrelationId().
You may need to move the looking for request logic before if..else to use the request in both cases.
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: If you go with that option please update the name for removeCurrentVoiceCommandWithCorrelationId accordingly
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: That will make the logic a bit simpler and align with iOS more
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: All previous comments here also apply to pendingVoiceCommandWithCorrelationId(). The logic can be simplified in a similar manner
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

replies.bodyText: Changed as suggested, new method names are removeCurrentVoiceCommandForCorrelatingDeleteCommand and pendingVoiceCommandForCorrelatingAddCommand
replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText: You can exit out of the loop when you find the item

replies.bodyText: change no longer needed with changes to onResponse method

timeline.bodyText: I don't think the list equals method works out of the box for custom objects. I believe you will need to override hashCode() and equals() in VoiceCommand to make the list.equals() method work. you can check SoftButtonObject as an example to see how to implement that.
timeline.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: The message is no longer accurate if the new list equals the old one
